config.content:
I'll be honest with you — I almost didn't write this article.

My team has been getting dozens of messages every week from women in the community asking me the same question: "Sarah, is Bloom or Kiala better?" And for a while, I resisted doing a head-to-head comparison because I don't love playing favorites publicly. That's not really my style.

But then I actually sat down with both supplement facts panels. And what I found wasn't a close call. It wasn't even in the same category. One of these products has serious formulation issues that most women would never catch — and the other has something I've rarely seen in this space: real clinical evidence behind its core ingredient.

So here we are. Let me walk you through exactly what I found.

The First Thing I Check: Serving Size and Transparency

When I evaluate any supplement for my clients, I start in the same place every time — the supplement facts panel. Not the marketing. Not the Instagram feed. The label.

Bloom's serving size is 5.64 grams. That's about a teaspoon and a half. Into that tiny amount, they've crammed seven separate proprietary blends: fiber, green superfood, pre/probiotic, fruit and vegetable, antioxidant beauty, digestive enzyme, and adaptogenic. Seven categories in what amounts to a heaping teaspoon of powder.

A registered dietitian reviewing Bloom in 2026 noted the product contains barely 1.5 grams of actual greens per serving — with no indication of the actual nutrient amounts per dose. Without that transparency, neither you nor I can assess whether these ingredients are present in amounts that would actually do anything.

Kiala's serving size is 8.3 grams — 50% more product per scoop. And rather than fragmenting into seven micro-blends with undisclosed amounts, Kiala concentrates its formula around six organic anchor ingredients — spirulina, chlorella, kale, wheatgrass, acai, and coconut water powder — plus a clinically studied antioxidant complex called Spectra®.

Fewer categories. More substance where it matters.

The Ingredient That Changed My Mind: Spectra®

I want to explain why this matters, because it's the single biggest differentiator between these two products — and most comparison articles miss it entirely.

Bloom doesn't have a clinically studied core ingredient. It has ingredients that have been studied individually in other contexts, but there's no validated, proprietary complex at the center of its formula with human clinical trials.

Kiala does.

Spectra® is a blend of 30+ fruits, vegetables, and herbs with two published peer-reviewed studies — including a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in human participants. Not a test tube. Not a petri dish. Real women and men, real blood draws, real measurements.

The study, published in the Journal of Food Science and Nutrition (Nemzer, Fink & Fink, 2014), found that Spectra® reduced cellular free radical production by up to 17%, achieved 3.5x inhibition of superoxide generation, nearly completely inhibited hydrogen peroxide formation, more than doubled the inhibition of cellular inflammatory response, and increased bioavailable nitric oxide — which supports circulation, cardiovascular function, and the delivery of nutrients throughout the body.

In over a decade of analyzing supplements for clients, I rarely encounter ingredients with this level of published human evidence. This is not marketing language. This is peer-reviewed science.

config.content:
The Gut Health Approach: Different Philosophies

Bloom and Kiala take fundamentally different approaches to digestive support, and understanding this difference helps explain why results can vary so much between users.

Bloom focuses on a probiotic-centric approach with their Pre and Probiotic Blend (648mg), listing specific strains like Bifidobacterium bifidum and Lactobacillus rhamnosus. However, they don't disclose CFU counts — the standard measure of probiotic potency. Most clinical probiotic research uses doses of 1 billion CFU or higher, so without this information, it's difficult to assess therapeutic potential.

Their formula also includes chicory root fructo-oligosaccharides in the fiber blend. While prebiotics can be beneficial, chicory root is a known high-FODMAP compound that can cause gas and bloating in sensitive individuals — which seems counterproductive for a product marketed for bloating relief.

Kiala takes a different path: antioxidant-based digestive support. The organic chlorella and spirulina provide gentle detoxification support. The coconut water powder delivers natural electrolytes. And the Spectra® blend's antioxidant activity helps reduce oxidative stress that contributes to digestive inflammation. It's less about flooding the gut with probiotics and more about creating optimal conditions for gut function.

Both approaches have merit, but for women dealing with unpredictable digestive reactions, the antioxidant approach tends to be gentler and more consistent.

Why Taste Is Actually a Clinical Concern

This might sound superficial, but it's not. In over a decade of working with clients, I've learned that the most effective supplement is the one you actually take every day. Compliance is the most underrated variable in nutritional supplementation.

Bloom's stevia-based sweetening has generated significant consumer complaints around taste. When a product is something you have to force yourself to drink, your compliance drops within two weeks — and so do your results.

Kiala comes in flavors like Miami Vice, Watermelon Slush, Tropical Splash, and Orange Sherbet that women in our community genuinely look forward to drinking. That's not vanity. That's a compliance strategy — and compliance is what produces the results you're actually looking for.

The Price Comparison

Let me address this directly because cost matters — especially when you're maintaining a daily wellness routine over months and years.

Bloom costs $39.99 for 30 servings — about $1.33 per serving. Kiala costs $34.97 — about $1.17 per serving. That's $5 less per month, or $60 per year.

But the real value calculation isn't just price per serving — it's what you're getting per dollar spent. Kiala gives you 50% more product per scoop (8.3g vs 5.5g), a clinically studied antioxidant core that Bloom doesn't have, no maltodextrin, no soy, no high-FODMAP lead ingredient, and a 45-day money-back guarantee. Dollar for dollar, it's not a close comparison.

faqs.question: "How is this different from the supplements I've already tried?"
faqs.answer: Most supplements address individual symptoms—a B vitamin for energy, magnesium for sleep, etc. This addresses the underlying system: your gut-hormone axis. When that functions properly, many symptoms resolve on their own. It's the difference between putting out individual fires and fixing the faulty wiring.

faqs.question: "I've tried greens powders before and didn't notice anything."
faqs.answer: Most greens powders contain sugar alcohols that actually irritate the gut, proprietary blends with undisclosed (often weak) doses, and no clinical backing. This formula is different: transparent dosing, Spectra® with published human trials, and nothing that undermines what you're trying to build.

faqs.question: "How long before I notice something?"
faqs.answer: Most women in our community report subtle shifts in sleep and energy by week 2-3. Clearer thinking often follows by week 4-6. But this isn't a quick fix—it's building a foundation. Give it 60 days before judging. That's why there's a 45-day guarantee.

faqs.question: "What if I have a 'mortifying moment' anyway?"
faqs.answer: You might. Life doesn't stop being stressful. But here's what Linda told me: 'Even when I get nervous now, I recover faster. The floor doesn't fall out.' That's what a solid foundation gives you—not perfection, but resilience.

config.content:
My Final Word

I didn't write this article to sell you something. I wrote it because women deserve honest information from someone who reads the labels, understands the science, and doesn't have an influencer deal clouding their judgment.

Bloom introduced millions of women to daily greens. That's worth acknowledging. But introducing someone to a category and being the best product in that category are two very different things.

If you've been on Bloom and feel like something's missing — the bloating hasn't fully resolved, the energy boost never materialized, or you're just tired of the aftertaste — it might be time to try the greens powder that over a million women have already switched to. Your body will tell you the difference. Give it 7 days.
